Let p:X⇝Yp : X \rightsquigarrow Yp:X⇝Y be a profunctor between small categories. Consider the collage X⊎pYX\uplus_p YX⊎p​Y, also called cograph, of $p$. One among many possible intuition for X⊎pYX\uplus_p YX⊎p​Y is that p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y) is a set of "fake arrows" x↘yx \searrow yx↘y, that in X⊎pYX\uplus_p YX⊎p​Y become real arrows. The fact that each p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y) can be seen as such a set of arrows is embodied in the request that there is a cowedge X(x,x′)×p(x′,y)→p(x,y)X(x,x')\times p(x',y)\to p(x,y)X(x,x′)×p(x′,y)→p(x,y) for each x,yx,yx,y.

Now, I would like to know what is the category that results from formally inverting the arrows in X⊎pYX\uplus_p YX⊎p​Y contained in the various p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y), or in other words, I want to consider the category of fractions X⊎pY[Σp−1]X\uplus_p Y[\Sigma_p^{-1}]X⊎p​Y[Σp−1​], where Σp=∐x,y∈X×Yp(x,y)\Sigma_p = \coprod_{x,y\in X\times Y} p(x,y)Σp​=∐x,y∈X×Y​p(x,y).

I suspect this is something already well-known; yet, I don't see any relevant property that might present X⊎pY[Σp−1]X\uplus_p Y[\Sigma_p^{-1}]X⊎p​Y[Σp−1​] as another guy in disguise. An interesting observation is that this construction always yields a nontrivial result (as soon as ppp is nonempty: this because an inverse to f∈p(x,y)f\in p(x,y)f∈p(x,y) is an arrow y→xy\to xy→x, i.e. an element of a set X⊎pY(y,x)X\uplus_p Y(y,x)X⊎p​Y(y,x) that previously was empty.
random guess: if the cograph is a lax colimit, i don't suppose what you're doing here might possibly be a pseudo colimit? image.png

A motivation, which is also the example I care about now:

Let X,YX,YX,Y be two posets, and let RRR be a profunctor between them regarded as categories; RRR is a relation between PPP and QQQ with the property of being downward closed on one side, and upward closed on the other side. For reasons irrelevant to the discussion, I want to look at functors F:P→SetF : P \to {\sf Set}F:P→Set with the property that, for a certain relation RRR on PPP compatible with the order, (a,b)∈R(a,b)\in R(a,b)∈R implies Fa≅FbFa \cong FbFa≅Fb.

I have never seen such a thing before, and this broader picture seems the right one into which this can be framed.

sarahzrf said:

what you're doing here might possibly be a pseudo colimit? image.png

Sure; in the end, a category of fractions is a particular instance of a coinverter!

In the case of a representable profunctor Hom(−,F−)\mathrm{Hom}(-,F-)Hom(−,F−) for a functor F:X→YF: X \to YF:X→Y, its collage can be built as a kind of “directed mapping cylinder” for the functor FFF, with the walking arrow category III playing the role of the interval: it's isomorphic to the quotient ((X×I)⨿Y)/∼((X \times I) \amalg Y)/\sim((X×I)⨿Y)/∼, where ∼\sim∼ identifies X×{1}X \times \{1\}X×{1} and YYY along FFF.

Presumably your “localised” version can be constructed in the same way, except now we replace III with the “walking isomorphism” category I≃I_\simeqI≃​?

For the general (non-representable) case, I think it should be possible to build the collage in a similar way. First we replace a profunctor ppp with the corresponding two-sided discrete fibration X←Ep→YX \leftarrow E_p \to YX←Ep​→Y. Then the collage is a quotient of X⨿(Ep×I)⨿YX \amalg (E_p \times I) \amalg YX⨿(Ep​×I)⨿Y where Ep×{0}E_p \times \{0\}Ep​×{0} is identified with XXX and Ep×{1}E_p \times \{1\}Ep​×{1} with YYY along the two legs of the fibration.
And then again, the localised version should be the same thing with I≃I_\simeqI≃​ replacing III.
(I've only tested that this is equivalent to what I said above in the representable case, so I may be wrong -- but I think it feels right...)
I was hoping for something like this, yes. I'll check tomorrow!
